repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Non-profit organization founded in 1975, based in Washington, DC, whose chief focus is promoting changes in U.S. foreign and military policy in support of global human rights. The records of the Center for International Policy (CIP) span the years 1960 to 2016, and document in detail the organization's global activities in support of human rights as well as its internal administration, funding, and public relations outreach. CIP's chief areas of interest lie in United States foreign and military policies, including the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA); topics cover human rights issues, U.S. relations with Central and South America, demilitarization, nuclear weapons, the Cuban trade embargo, money laundering and other aspects of international finance, terrorism, and the narcotics trade. The bulk of the files take the form of administrative files and records which contain correspondence, memos, data, reports, travel documents, and extensive files on other organizations; there are also many files of printed materials such as pamphlets, newsletters, and press releases.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Center for International Policy Records, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Center for International Policy Records were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2005, 2013, and 2015.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Web content described by Michelle Runyon, April 2020.
Accession(s) described in this collection guide: 2005-0121, 2012-0074, 2013-0122, and 2015-0168.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Center for International Policy (CIP), a non-governmental non-profit organization, was founded in 1975 primarily in response to the Vietnam War, and is currently (2007) based in Washington D.C. Its mission is to reform the activities of United States foreign and military policies in support of human rights in all countries. The records housed at Duke correspond to three important CIP associates: Robert White, Adam Issacson and Selig Harrison.

Robert White was hired as president of the Center for International Policy (CIP) in 1989 and served until his death in 2015. Prior to joining the CIP, White spent twenty-five years in the Foreign Service, specializing in Latin American affairs with a particular emphasis on Central America. Among the posts he held were Latin America Director of the Peace Corps, Deputy Permanent Representative to the Organization of American States, Ambassador to Paraguay and to El Salvador. After retiring from the Foreign Service in 1981, White served as a Senior Associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. During his tenure at the CIP, he presided at conferences and led delegations to several Latin American and Caribbean countries, published numerous studies of U.S. policy toward the region, and led an ongoing effort to reform U.S. intelligence agencies.

The CIP's Programs Director, Adam Isacson, was hired as program director for the Colombia and Demilitarization of Latin American program in 1995. Prior to that he worked for the Arias Foundation for Peace and Human Progress in San Jos√©, Costa Rica. Mr. Isacson has worked on Latin American security issues, particularly U.S. policy toward Central America and Colombia. He has been to Colombia more than twenty-five times and visited thirteen of the country's thirty-two departments.

The CIP's director of the Asia Project, Selig Harrison, is a senior scholar of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars and director of the Century Foundation's Program on the United States and the Future of Korea. He has specialized in South Asia and East Asia for fifty years as a journalist and scholar, including as a South Asia correspondent of the Associated Press. Selig Harrison became one of the first Americans to visit North Korea since the Korean War and to interview Kim Il Sung in 1972.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The records of the Center for International Policy (CIP) span the years 1960 to 2016, and document in detail the organization's global activities in support of human rights as well as its internal administration, funding, and public relations outreach. CIP's chief areas of interest lie in documenting and reforming United States foreign and military policies, including the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA). Specific topics covered by materials in the collection include U.S. relations with Central and South America, particularly with Colombia, El Salvador, Haiti, and Cuba; U.S. relations with South and East Asia, particularly the Korean Peninsula; demilitarization in areas of conflict; nuclear weapons and the arms race; the Cuban trade embargo; money laundering and other aspects of international finance; terrorism in various countries; and the narcotics trade. The bulk of the files take the form of administrative files and records on other organizations which contain correspondence, memos, data, reports, travel documents, and extensive files; there are also many files containing printed materials such as pamphlets, newsletters, and press releases.

White's and Isacson's files retain their original arrangement into groups such as correspondence (some in digital form), research and subject files, speeches, and travel documentation. Harrison's files retain their original arrangment by region, such South and West Asia, East Asia and North Korea, while some materials have been removed to the Nuclear and Energy Subseries. The research files claim the largest proportion of the files for all individuals, and contain documentation on other organizations, individuals, and extensive information in particular on Central and South America and Asia. Other countries represented in the collection files to a lesser extent include Russia, Israel, Cuba and other countries surrounding the South and East Asia regions. Correspondence files are present throughout the collection, and include key individuals such as Iowa Senator Tom Harkin; Peter Dale Scott, former Canadian ambassador and political commentator; and Harrison Selig, Director of the Asia Program. Many other well-known politicians and activists are represented in smaller folders of materials; there are also a small number of administrative files related to internal staff members and board members. The development files reveal the nature of the CIP's fundraising activities, and the extent of support from charitable organizations; the most extensive files belong to the Ford Foundation, General Service Foundation, International Center for Development Policy, and the MacArthur Foundation; smaller files represent many other similar institutions.
Collection acquired as part of the Human Rights Archive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains papers relating to development and funding at the Center for International Policy. The papers take two forms: grant proposals addressed to the various donors of the Center, or subject files detailing the work of the various programs at the Center with materials used in the grant writing process. Typically the documents were written by a number of staff members within the office. Organized alphabetically by name.

did.unittitle: International Center for Development Policy correspondence (3 folders), 1986-1987
International Center for Development Policy proposals (1-2 of 4 folders), 1982-1992
International Center for Development Policy proposals (3-4 of 4 folders), 1982-1992

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Collection of printed materials relating to the Center for International Policy include press releases (which mention CIP or a staff member), International Policy Reports (published by CIP), and various articles written by staff members. Materials are arranged alphabetically by author's last name or subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains the working files created by Robert White, a president of the Center for International Policy. White was hired as president of the Center for International Policy (CIP) in 1989, a position he held until his death in 2015. During his tenure at the CIP, he presided at conferences and led delegations to several Latin American and Caribbean countries, published numerous studies of U.S. policy toward the region, and led an ongoing effort to reform U.S. intelligence agencies. White's files are divided into five subseries: Correspondence, People, Speeches, Subject Files, and Travel White's files are divided into five subseries: Correspondence, People, Speeches, Subject Files, and Travel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of the correspondence is addressed to White from various authors, and is business related. Files are arranged chronologically. Two folders entitled "V.I.P. letters" contain correspondence from high-ranking politicians, including Henry Kissinger, Senator John Kerry, and President Ronald Reagan; these letters are arranged alphabetically by last name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains research files collected by White on various individuals; arranged alphabetically by last name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This section contains final versions, often typed notes or transcripts, of speeches given by White on a variety of subjects. They are arranged chronologically. Also included are 2 folders containing official transcripts of testimony given by White before various government hearings and panels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains Robert White's research files, comprising the bulk of his papers. Arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains files house papers of Adam Isacson, a senior associate and program director of the Center for International Policy. Adam Isacson was hired as program director of the Colombia and Demilitarization of Latin America program in 1995. Prior to that he worked previously for the Arias Foundation for Peace and Human Progress in San Jos√©, Costa Rica. Mr. Isacson has worked on Latin American security issues, particularly U.S. policy toward Central America and Colombia. He has been to Colombia more than twenty-five times and visited thirteen of the country's thirty-two departments. Adam Isacson's papers are divided into four subseries: Correspondence, Speeches, Subject Files (the largest section), and Travel Files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of business-related exchanges between Isacson and various correspondents. There are also digital files of email correspondence. Arranged alphabetically by name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Additional subject files collected by Adam Isaacson during his tenure at CIP. Includes information about CIP programs and initiatives in Central America, particularly Colombia, as well as documentation of partner organizations (WOLA, Open Society Institute, etc.) and CIP internal administrative files regarding finances, Congressional spending and budgets, government agencies, and other activities by the Central America program. Some of the files relate to Isaacson's work on asylum cases for Colombia refugees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Isaacson's Colombia subject files on refugees, U.S. congressional hearings, CIP lobbying, and other working groups.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Files contain documents collected by Isacson while traveling on CIP business. They include speeches, travel documents, notes, receipts, and literature regarding his trip. Included in this sub-suberies are three notebooks in which Isacson writes in great detail about conversations, meetings, and impressions of his trips to Colombia in 2001 and 2004. Arranged alphabetically by folder title.

did.unittitle: Carnegie Seminar, New York, NY, 2002 Oct. 21-22
Colombia Support Network, Madison, Wisc., 2003 Apr. 3-5
University of Southern California, Los Angeles, Ca., 2003 Apr. 8-10

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accession (2012-0074) contains papers of Selig Harrison, a senior associate and program director of the Asia Project for the Center for International Policy. He is also a senior scholar of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars and director of the Century Foundation's Program on the United States and the Future of Korea. He has specialized in South Asia and East Asia for fifty years as a journalist and scholar, including as a South Asia correspondent of the Associated Press. Selig Harrison became one of the first Americans to visit North Korea since the Korean War and to interview Kim Il Sung in 1972. Harrison's papers are divided into three subseries: Geographic (the largest section), Nuclear and Energy, and Professional. Additional materials from Selig Harrison can be found in the Audiovisual Materials Series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of business-related exchanges between Harrison and various correspondents; newspaper clippings and other current events material regarding the economy and politics of Asian countries, including the tensions and relations in and between these countries; travel documents; and drafts of articles and speeches. Files are arranged first by region, including South and West Asia, East Asia, North Korea, and interregional and other regions, and then alphabetically by name. Some materials have been removed to the Nuclear and Energy Subseries, the Professional Subseries and the Audiovisual Subseries. Materials dealing exclusively with North Korea have been removed to the North Korea Subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains files related to nuclear armament and disarmament, especially regarding negotiations to denuclearize the Korean peninsula, arms sales, sanctions, and other nuclear incidents in various regions. Also contains files related to various energy programs, sometimes nuclear but especially regarding oil and gas resources in Russia and Northeast Asia, and energy development programs and proposals in this region. Files are organized alphabetically by name. Some materials have been removed to the Professional Subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence and other documentation regarding Harrison's submissions and publications with various media outlets, including his source material, speeches delivered at workshops and other events on various subjects, documentation of the organization and attendance of professional workshops, published pieces, and other general professional records related to the Center for International Policy, the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, and the Century Foundation. Files are organized alphabetically by name. More speeches and manuscripts can be found in the Geographic and Nuclear and Energy subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains files collected and created by Wayne S. Smith as part of his work with Center for International Policy. The materials include subject and research files on Cuba and U.S. trade and social policy, as well as writings by Smith opposing the U.S. Cuba embargo and travel restrictions, and travel files from Smith's work escorting students and lawmakers to Cuba on diplomatic and cultural missions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Loosely arranged by year. Includes Smith's files and correspondence on events and conferences such as: The U.S. and Soviet Union in Latin America (1991); Cuba Transition workshop (1995); the Helms-Burton Act conference (1997); and the Consequences of Unilateralism (1998). Also includes his materials from various trips to Cuba.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Loosely arranged by year. Includes Smtih's events and conferences such as: Afro-Cuban conference (1999); CIP Board trip to Cuba (1999); Cross Cultural Journeys trips (1999, 2000); the U.S. and Cuban Trademarks conference (2001); trips to Cuba; and various lectures and trips visiting American universities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Loosely arranged by year. Includes Smith's correspondence and files regarding events and conferences, such as: Cuban Missile Crisis 40th anniversary conference (2002); Cross Cultural Journeys trips (2003); Conference on Bush's New Cuban Policy (2004); National Summit on Cuba (2004, 2005); Guantanamo conference (2005); and others. Also includes materials from Smith's various trips to Cuba.

scopecontent.p: Trial transcripts of CANF's libel case against Wayne Smith; foldered as volumes 1-8.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Smith's assorted articles, editorials, reports, and book reviews spanning the 1970s through the 2000s. Topics include U.S. policy in Cuba, Fidel Castro, Latin America/Soviet relations, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains an array of documentation created by and collected by CIP program staff in support of various initiatives including promotion of democracy in Latin America, anti-corruption programs, anti-landmine programs and policies, and environmental protection policies. Programs represented include the CIP Central America Program (and its director, Elsa Chang), the Democracy without Borders project in Honduras; country programs in Nicaragua, Guatemala, and Colombia; and many files from various organizations working with CIP in political or fundraising partnerships. Also includes drafts of the CIP report "Commander in Chief", discussing the role of the American president in international treaties over landmines and chemical weapsons. Materials are loosely arranged by topic and are described at the box level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: CIP research files and collected information for Colombia briefing book; some correspondence and draft proposals for a meeting between US and FARC officials in the 2000s; Victims of the Armed Conflict project files (Medellin); CIP Colombia policy drafts and statements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: CIP agency files regarding conditions and politics in El Salvador, collected and created by CIP staff. Includes materials from El Marcha, 2007-2008; CIP's Blue Democracy project (Democracia Azul), 2007-2008; and files from Robert White regarding El Salvador and his ambassadorship there, 2002-2007. Some of the Robert White material relates to a book draft, proposed and researched about White's time in El Salvador. Also includes a substantial amount of photocopied and gathered reports, declassified telegrams and other archival documents, and press releases regarding 1980s El Salvadorian death squads; includes materials collected about the murders of four U.S. churchwomen and subsequent investigations and trials.

did.unittitle: Fundacion Democracia sin Fronteras (FDsF) / Democracy without Borders: Administration and reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes administrative, funding, and logistical files from various meetings held by FDsF, as well as a briefing book and revised constitution from the founding of the NGO by CIP. Contains some scattered annual reports and media coverage. Programs mentioned include the FDsF inauguration, held in Honduras in 2006, as well as the Mateo city program and the Transparency and Access to Information program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files related to CIP activities in Honduras, particularly regarding violence stemming from illegal logging and deforestation. Includes some FDsF materials, as well as research and documentation of negotiations and confrontations between loggers and the military in Olancho versus the MAO (Olancho's Environmental Movement) and other civilians. Includes materials researching the death of anti-logging activist Carlos Reyes. CIP staff represented include Adam Isaacson, Elsa Chang, and Robert White, among others. There is also extensive material from the CIP-sponsored Marcha Nacional por la Vida, held in June 2004 to protest deforestation in Honduras, as well as material documenting the at-times contentious relationship between CIP and EIA (Environmental Investigation Agency). Some other topics represented by subject files include CAFTA (Central America Free Trade Agreement), mining, corruption, the 2005 election, and human rights in Honduras.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Budget proposals, program workplans, and statutes from the founding of the FDsF, as well as other country programs within the CIP's Central America Program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject files, correspondence, published NGO handouts, and clippings collected by CIP regarding Guatemalan government corruption, mining, and violence/human rights violations. Largely dating from the 2000s but includes copies of earlier materia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Largely files relating to CIP and FDsF's exposure and investigation into illegal logging in Nicaragua, including reports, conferences, a contract with Environmental Impact Agency (EIA), plans for press releases and a documentary, and event files. Includes Bob Levinson's research into the Nicaraguan forest mafia. Also includes some research materials regarding Nicaragua political conditions in the 1980s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Press coverage and clippings regarding illegal logging in Central America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Assorted articles and press coverage of Central American politics, events, and other CIP-related subjects, collected by CIP staff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seminar packets for assorted institutes, clippings and research articles, and other materials collected and created by CIP Africa Program staff. Minimal correspondence or programmatic files; appears to be largely research and reference material. Countries include Senegal, Angola, and Nigeria; files also contain material regarding American foreign relations and security in Africa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Assorted materials researching and documenting United States and other European country military spending in African, Central American, and Asian countries. Includes materials related to terrorism, arms control, training expenditures and programs, and other topics of interest to CIP such as oil and political elections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Research files and program material for various initiatives in the 1990s and early 2000s seeking to ban and disarm landmines and other explosives used globally during military occupation and war. Includes materials from the Ottawa Treaty to ban mines; publications and press releases from demilitarization and anti-mine organizations and CIP programs like Demilitarization for Democracy and the International Campaign to Ban Landmines; Congressional and international legislative efforts; press articles, pamphlets, and coverage of the devestation caused by landmines; and materials documenting the U.S. refusal to join treaties banning landmines. One file includes an autographed letter from President Bill Clinton explaining his administration's refusal to endorse a full ban on landmines.

did.unittitle: "Commander-In-Chief: The Role of Presidential Leadership in Efforts to Ban the Use of Chemical Weapons and Landmines," CIP report: drafts and sources

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Assorted files for different agencies collected by CIP staff, including Associacion para una Sociedad Justa (ASJ), IRELA, Partners for Democractic Change, Earthworks, Transparency International, CEDHA, and others.
